perturbation.original_text: (jj) "Assigned Know-How" means all of the Know-How owned by any Seller Party as of the Initial Closing Date that was created by a Business Employee, including the Know-How set forth on Schedule 1.1(j).   2
perturbation.changed_text: (jj) "Assigned Know-How" means some of the Know-How owned by any Seller Party as of the Initial Closing Date, whether or not it was created by a Business Employee, potentially including the Know-How set forth on Schedule 1.1(j).   2
perturbation.explanation: The original text clearly defines “Assigned Know-How” as that created by a 'Business Employee'. Modifying this to 'some of the Know-How' and adding 'whether or not it was created by a Business Employee' creates conflict and broadens the definition. This introduces ambiguity regarding the ownership and transfer of intellectual property, deviating from standard IP definitions.

perturbation.original_text: (kk) "Intellectual Property" means any and all of the following in any jurisdiction throughout the world: (i) patents, patent applications, industrial design rights (including utility model rights, design rights, and industrial property rights), registrations and applications for registration of industrial design rights, patents of importation/confirmation, statutory invention registrations, and certificates of invention and like statutory right, all counterparts, continuations, divisions, continuations-in-part, revisions, extensions, supplementary certificates, substitutions, reexaminations, renewals, and reissuances of any of the foregoing and any patent or patent application that claims priority to any of the foregoing (collectively, "Patents"); (ii) Trademarks; (iii) copyright registrations and applications, and unregistered copyrights, published and unpublished works of authorship, and Mask Works, together with all applications, registrations, and renewals in connection therewith, and all common-law rights to any of the foregoing (collectively, "Copyrights"); (iv) computer programs, whether embodied in software, firmware or otherwise, including, software compilations, software implementations of algorithms, software tool sets, compilers, and software models and methodologies (whether in Source Code or Object Code form), and (C) translation, ported   5
perturbation.changed_text: (kk) "Intellectual Property" means some of the following in certain jurisdictions: (i) certain patents, patent applications, industrial design rights (including utility model rights, design rights, and industrial property rights), registrations and applications for registration of industrial design rights, patents of importation/confirmation, statutory invention registrations, and certificates of invention and like statutory right, some counterparts, some continuations, some divisions, continuations-in-part, revisions, extensions, supplementary certificates, substitutions, reexaminations, renewals, and reissuances of any of the foregoing and any patent or patent application that claims priority to any of the foregoing (potentially, "Patents"); (ii) Potentially Trademarks; (iii) copyright registrations and applications, potentially unregistered copyrights, some published and unpublished works of authorship, and potentially Mask Works, maybe with all applications, registrations, and renewals maybe in connection therewith, and maybe all common-law rights potentially to any of the foregoing (perhaps "Copyrights"); (iv) potentially computer programs, perhaps whether embodied in software, firmware or otherwise, potentially including, some software compilations, some software implementations of algorithms, some software tool sets, compilers, and software models and methodologies (maybe in Source Code or Object Code form), and (C) translation, ported   5
perturbation.explanation: The definition of "Intellectual Property" is being modified from an encompassing statement to a vague and uncertain one. The inclusion of terms like "some", "potentially", and "maybe" directly undermines the reliability of this agreement regarding intellectual property rights, making enforcement nearly impossible due to the lack of clarity. It introduces subjectivity where objectivity is required, making contract terms unenforceable due to vagueness and creates dispute for contract interpretation.

perturbation.original_text: (xxxx) "Trademarks" means (i) trademarks, service marks, logos, product numbers, trade dress, trade names, corporate names and Internet domain names, slogans, and   11
perturbation.changed_text: (xxxx) "Trademarks" could mean (i) potentially trademarks, service marks, maybe logos, potentially product numbers, perhaps trade dress, and corporate names and Internet domain names, slogans, perhaps, and   11
perturbation.explanation: The original definition of "Trademarks" includes specific types of intellectual property, providing a clear scope. The modified definition introduces uncertainty by using terms like "could mean", "potentially", and "maybe", which directly contradicts the need for precise legal definitions in intellectual property agreements. The ambiguity in this definition may lead to disputes over which marks are covered by the agreement, potentially rendering the trademark provisions unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Trademark Law, Contract Law - Definiteness of Terms
